title: Are snowflakes actually just small pieces of ice? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes! With a few impurities, of course. But only in the sense that the computer chip in your smartphone is just a piece of silicon. With a few impurities, of course. Both are surprisingly pure single crystals of single substances, and both of those substances have any number of rather remarkable properties. But also in both cases, it's the incredibly detailed structure of the crystals that is where the real story is.  For computer chips, that incredibly detailed structure is mostly computer-made, with help from a few clever humans who let the computers know what is needed. For snowflakes the structure is also amazingly detailed, but also (and unlike computer chips), beautifully symmetric in a six-fold fashion. The design method here is also extremely detailed, but in sharp contrast to computer chips, it is new and pretty much unique for every single snowflake, even in a typical storm with quintillions of snowflakes. So how does a snowstorm manage to create a unique and somehow symmetric design for each and every one of its snowflakes, something that no team of computers and humans could ever do for computer chips? The answer is chaos… but chaos that smooths out just before it reaches the size scale of snowflakes. A thunderstorm is a maelstrom of winds, pressures, temperatures, and humidity. All of these factors affect the speed and directions in which ice faces develop once a crystal begins to grow from some speck of seed dust, and all of these factors are interacting and changing at great speeds, often at millisecond time scales. Yet at the minute size scale of snowflakes, all of this chaos smooths out enough to give a sequence of remarkably uniform microenvironments in which ice is added almost identically across all six edges of the snowflake. It is this smoothness-at-the-bottom that is the source of the remarkable symmetry of snowflakes. The “program” for the design of any one snowflake, then, is the sequence of these microenvironments that the snowflake encounters as it grows, including the duration and transitions between them. So the bottom line again is yes, a snowflake is just ice. But it is also a testimony to the remarkable complexity and beauty that can emerge from a few relatively simple options, especially when those options are combined with a healthy dose of chaos to add variety.

No, they are not. Snowflakes are crystals of ice. They have crystallized out from the water vapor in the air. These crystals have six-fold symmetry and remarkably complex design. Ice that is solidified from liquid water does not form such crystalline structures ; ice cubes are more amorphous than crystalline. If you smash up an ice cube, you will get a “piece of ice” the same sizes as snowflakes, but never having their crystalline structure or physical properties.

Are snowflakes actually just small pieces of ice? No, they are not. Though they are made of the same basic ingredient—water—they are two different forms. Ice is solidified water and snow is the crystalline form. Examine the two pictures below. One is snow flakes, the other of hail—which are small balls of ice.

Sort of. But not really. Ice and snow come from ice crystals. The ice crystals that form snow are in a regular formation and have air spaces between them. Ice forms when the ice crystals form sheets or chunks and I assume very few air spaces. For a fuller explanation see What’s the difference between snow and ice?
